messageBody:
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>> >The short answer: there is a way to make JUnit do this, but many of us
>> >don't like to do it that way. For a test like this, I might do the
>> >following:
>> >
>> >List failedUrls = new ArrayList();
>> >foreach (URL url : urlsToTest) {
>> > if (failed(url)) {
>> > failedUrls.add(url);
>> > }
>> >}
>> >assertTrue(failedUrls.isEmpty());
>> >
>> >
>> And then what? Are you going to use debugger to see what exactly
>> failed up there?
>>
> Fine.
>
> assertTrue(failedUrls.toString(), failedUrls.isEmpty());
>
> I really rather thought that would be obvious, so I didn't bother to
> write it.
>
I use to do this, but then I figured that it is much flexible to use
suite. It would also allow to run tests in parallel using simple
decorator and it will really reduce test time in case of the external
resource such as web server or database. I thought you would know that. ;-P

regards,
Eugene
